answers.author: Cliff Griffin
answers.text:
Our City recently adopted the following:
Meetings/Training:  Except in urgent or emergency situations, employees attending any meeting or training event, on or off-site, in which they are representing the City, will turn off or at a minimum, silence their cell phones/pagers.  If the employee is required to respond to the call or message, the employee should leave the meeting room to answer the call to minimize any disruption to the rest of the participants and trainer/presenter.  The City expects employees to exhibit this courtesy to the trainer/presenter and to the other employees and attendees who would otherwise become distracted.  Employees attempting to read or answer messages during meetings or training events may be reported to their immediate supervisor and department director for appropriate discussion and/or disciplinary action.

answers.author: Michael Baker
answers.text:
We have posted groundrules that we agreed upon internally for many of our regular meetings.  One of the groundrules states "no cell phones/email in room".  Although we don't strictly enforce, people generally understand the expectation and the importance of paying attention and contributing to the productivity of the group.  
If I were to observe behavior from an employee in violation of the groundrule, I can always go up to the person afterwards and politely offer some feedback about how their use of their cell phone causes a distraction and shows that they really don't appear interested in the effectiveness of the group.
